Without one, you’ll likely end up with something that doesn’t fit your expectations and you’ll have to go through multiple rounds of review and revisions to get an acceptable piece of work.","p2":"That means frustration for you, frustration for the creative worker, and most likely drastically increased costs.","p3":"So it really is worth taking the time to perfect your brief. But it’s not always obvious what should be included or excluded, which is why"},"what_is_a_brief":{"title":"What Is A Brief?","p1":"A brief is not an email or DM saying ‘can you make me a logo’. It is also not a 5000 word essay about what your inspirations are and why you think a green chimpanzee would be the best icon to describe your vision for your business","p2":"A brief is a document that succinctly explains your creative requirements. It should generally include:","point1":"What the required output is (logo, promotional video, website)","point2":"What is the purpose of the output (to promote your business, to win new customers, to attract more sign ups)","point3":"Who the target audience is ie. your end customer","point4":"What you’d like the target audience to do after interacting with your required output","point5":"What you’d like to communicate to your target audience","point6":"What tone of voice/look/feel you’re going for","point7":"Links to any examples of the required output you particularly like (logos you like, promotional videos you like, websites you like). Technical specifications (format, size, length) Required timeframe","p3":"And remember, the clue’s in the name. It’s a brief. You should only include helpful information and use short, clear, direct sentences. It should really be no more than 2 A4 size pages and ideally much shorter than that. If your brief is running longer, the person reading it may find it hard to follow, or hard to pick out which important details to focus on.","p4":"The specific things you need to include or exclude will change depending on the particular job, but if you take the above list as a guide you’ll find it hard to go wrong."},"what_are_the_benefits_of_a_brief":{"title":"What Are The Benefits Of A Brief?","point1":"Better results. If you’ve provided a good brief, you’re far likely to get results that match or exceed your expectations.","point2":"Faster results. With a great brief, you’ll almost certainly have far fewer rounds of feedback and revisions, which saves everyone time.","point3":"Avoiding scope/mission creep. A proper brief should clearly set the parameters of expected work. Without it, you’re more likely to find that the lines of what was asked for/expected get blurred and you’ll end up in disputes with the creative person you are working with about what are fair or reasonable requests.","point4":"Lower costs. A better brief means less time wasted and therefore you’ll likely end up spending less on the project"},"example":{"design_brief":{"title":"Example Design Brief","p1":"There are lots of ways to format a design brief, and the specifics can vary depending on the project. But we find this template works well for most design projects (logos, adverts, websites etc).","layout":{"question1":"PROJECT TITLE","answer1":"Quite simple, really. The title of your project.","question2":"CLIENT NAME & CONTACT","answer2":"Your name and contact details (email address, phone number).","question3":"BRAND","answer3":"The name of the business/organisation the design is for.","question4":"PRODUCT","answer4":"The specific product the design is for, if applicable.","question5":"DELIVERABLES","answer5":"What the required outputs are.","question6":"CHALLENGE","answer6":"What are you trying to do? Why does your business/organisation want the design work done, and what action would you like the viewers of your design to take? What are your goals?","question7":"TARGET AUDIENCE","answer7":"Who is your target audience? What are they like? You should share insights about their key behaviours and preferences to help guide the designer.","question8":"MESSAGE","answer8":"What key message are you trying to communicate to your target audience via the design?","question9":"TONE OF VOICE","answer9":"What is your brand tone of voice? What tone of voice would you like the design to convey? It’s a good idea to link to examples here.","question10":"GUIDELINES","answer10":"If you have brand guidelines, it’s a good idea to include them here so the designer knows what they are/are not allowed to do.","question11":"COMPETITION","answer11":"Who are your main competitors? What do you like/dislike about their designs?","question12":"FORMAT","answer12":"Specifications for the deliverables. Format, size, length. If it’s a website, you should include a sitemap and ideally the content you’ll need on the site (even if it’s just an outline).","question13":"TIMEFRAME","answer13":"When do you need the designs? Try to be reasonable."}},"creative_brief":{"title":"Example Creative Brief","p1":"A creative brief is similar to a design brief, but can be wider in scope eg - you want creative assets for an entire marketing campaign.
